## MATHEMATICS

9709/11  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 303, 310, 319]]<|/det|>
Paper 1 Pure Mathematics 1  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[784, 303, 907, 319]]<|/det|>
May/June 2023  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[760, 329, 907, 345]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 357, 395, 373]]<|/det|>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[96, 384, 390, 400]]<|/det|>
You will need: List of formulae (MF19)  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 418, 225, 434]]<|/det|>
## INSTRUCTIONS  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 435, 875, 632]]<|/det|>
INSTRUCTIONS- Answer all questions.- Use a black or dark blue pen. You may use an HB pencil for any diagrams or graphs.- Write your name, centre number and candidate number in the boxes at the top of the page.- Write your answer to each question in the space provided.- Do not use an erasable pen or correction fluid.- Do not write on any bar codes.- If additional space is needed, you should use the lined page at the end of this booklet; the question number or numbers must be clearly shown.- You should use a calculator where appropriate.- You must show all necessary working clearly; no marks will be given for unsupported answers from a calculator.- Give non-exact numerical answers correct to 3 significant figures, or 1 decimal place for angles in degrees, unless a different level of accuracy is specified in the question.  

<|ref|>sub_title<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 664, 216, 679]]<|/det|>
## INFORMATION  

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[95, 680, 732, 712]]<|/det|>
INFORMATION- The total mark for this paper is 75.- The number of marks for each question or part question is shown in brackets [ ].

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>3</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[232, 92, 796, 483]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 501, 631, 521]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows graphs with equations \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) and \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 530, 917, 551]]<|/det|>
Describe fully a sequence of two transformations which transforms the graph of \(y = \mathrm{f}(x)\) to \(y = \mathrm{g}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 546, 920, 565]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 73, 94, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>4</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[336, 87, 693, 230]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 250, 920, 288]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a sector \(ABC\) of a circle with centre \(A\) and radius \(8\mathrm{cm}\). The area of the sector is \(\frac{16}{3}\pi \mathrm{cm}^2\). The point \(D\) lies on the arc \(BC\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 300, 443, 319]]<|/det|>
Find the perimeter of the segment \(BCD\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 301, 920, 319]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>5</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 920, 120]]<|/det|>
The line with equation \(y = kx - k\), where \(k\) is a positive constant, is a tangent to the curve with equation \(y = - \frac{1}{2x}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 131, 920, 151]]<|/det|>
Find, in either order, the value of \(k\) and the coordinates of the point where the tangent meets the curve.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 147, 920, 165]]<|/det|>
<mark>[5]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 75, 97, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>8</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 705, 92]]<|/det|>
The functions f and g are defined as follows, where \(a\) and \(b\) are constants.

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[395, 100, 603, 131]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{f}(x) = 1 + \frac{2a}{x - a}\mathrm{for} x > a\]

<|ref|>equation<|/ref|><|det|>[[393, 135, 579, 155]]<|/det|>
\[\mathrm{g}(x) = bx - 2\mathrm{for}x\in \mathbb{R}\]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 177, 146, 195]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 176, 641, 195]]<|/det|>
Given that \(\mathrm{f}(7) = \frac{5}{2}\) and \(\mathrm{gf}(5) = 4\), find the values of \(a\) and \(b\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 177, 920, 195]]<|/det|>
<mark>[4]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 771, 92]]<|/det|>
For the rest of this question, you should use the value of \(a\) which you found in (a).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 104, 148, 122]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 103, 348, 122]]<|/det|>
Find the domain of \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 122]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 344, 186, 363]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[191, 344, 398, 363]]<|/det|>
Find an expression for \(\mathrm{f}^{-1}(x)\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 345, 920, 364]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[76, 73, 92, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>9</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 73, 920, 127]]<|/det|>
Water is poured into a tank at a constant rate of \(500\mathrm{cm}^3\) per second. The depth of water in the tank, \(t\) seconds after filling starts, is \(h\mathrm{cm}\). When the depth of water in the tank is \(h\mathrm{cm}\), the volume, \(V\mathrm{cm}^3\), of water in the tank is given by the formula \(V = \frac{4}{3} (25 + h)^3 - \frac{62500}{3}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 139, 146, 158]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 139, 698, 158]]<|/det|>
Find the rate at which \(h\) is increasing at the instant when \(h = 10 \text{cm}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 139, 920, 158]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 757, 92]]<|/det|>
At another instant, the rate at which \(h\) is increasing is \(0.075 \text{cm}\) per second.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 104, 432, 123]]<|/det|>
Find the value of \(V\) at this instant.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 104, 920, 123]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 73, 148, 91]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
A triangle is formed from the tangent to the curve at \(B\), the normal to the curve at \(B\) and the \(x\)-axis.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 120, 390, 138]]<|/det|>
Find the area of this triangle.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 120, 920, 138]]<|/det|>
<mark>[6]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[77, 75, 104, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>12</label>

<|ref|>image<|/ref|><|det|>[[279, 87, 742, 437]]<|/det|>


<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[118, 454, 920, 507]]<|/det|>
The diagram shows a circle \(P\) with centre (0, 2) and radius 10 and the tangent to the circle at the point \(A\) with coordinates (6, 10). It also shows a second circle \(Q\) with centre at the point where this tangent meets the \(y\)-axis and with radius \(\frac{5}{2}\sqrt{5}\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 518, 146, 537]]<|/det|>
<label>(a)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[154, 518, 448, 537]]<|/det|>
Write down the equation of circle \(P\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 518, 920, 537]]<|/det|>
<mark>[1]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 662, 148, 681]]<|/det|>
<label>(b)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 662, 571, 681]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of the tangent to the circle \(P\) at \(A\).

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 662, 920, 681]]<|/det|>
<mark>[2]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[116, 74, 146, 92]]<|/det|>
<label>(c)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 73, 920, 108]]<|/det|>
Find the equation of circle \(Q\) and hence verify that the \(y\)-coordinates of both of the points of intersection of the two circles are 11.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 87, 920, 106]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[156, 526, 186, 545]]<|/det|>
<label>(d)</label>

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[158, 524, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
Find the coordinates of the points of intersection of the tangent and circle \(Q\), giving the answers in surd form.

<|ref|>text<|/ref|><|det|>[[890, 541, 920, 560]]<|/det|>
<mark>[3]
